user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddSubTest:
```c
void UtTest_AddSubTest(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *GroupName,
                       const char *TestName)
{
    char        CompleteTestName[128];
    const char *GroupPtr;
    const char *TestPtr;

    /* Remove any common prefix between the two names.
     * They are often function names that all start with "Test_XXX"
     * and this repetitive information just becomes clutter.
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    TestPtr  = TestName;
    while (*GroupPtr != 0 && *GroupPtr == *TestPtr)
    {
        ++GroupPtr;
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Only break at an underscore(_) to avoid weird effects
     */
    while (TestPtr > TestName && *TestPtr != '_')
    {
        --TestPtr;
    }
    if (*TestPtr == '_')
    {
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Remove a remaining "Test_" prefix on the group name.
     * Again just to remove common repetitive content
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    if (strncmp(GroupPtr, "Test_", 5) == 0)
    {
        GroupPtr += 5;
    }

    (void)snprintf(CompleteTestName, sizeof(CompleteTestName), "%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr);

    UtTest_AddCommon(Test, Setup, Teardown, CompleteTestName, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_AddSubTest:
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter variables are modified in the provided code. The parameters of UtTest_AddSubTest are: Test, Setup, Teardown, GroupName, and TestName. The code only creates local pointer variables (GroupPtr and TestPtr) and modifies those (advancing/retreating them) — this is allowed because the rule forbids modifying the parameter variables themselves, not objects referred to or local copies of pointers. GroupName and TestName are never assigned to or incremented/decremented directly. The call to UtTest_AddCommon simply passes the parameter pointers; inside UtTest_AddCommon the TestName parameter is only read (and its contents copied via strncpy into a local structure), and the pointer variables of UtTest_AddCommon are not modified. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the given code.
